channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Armies Used by U.N. Fail Watchdog Group’s Test
item.description: A new study found that the armed forces that provide the most United Nations peacekeepers are also among the world’s most susceptible to corruption.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Leaked Files Detail Offshore Accounts Tied to World Leaders
item.description: A group of news media outlets said the documents revealed the offshore accounts of 140 global politicians, including several figures with close ties to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:description: The documents revealed the offshore accounts of 140 politicians and public officials, including several individuals with close ties to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

item.title: China’s Companies Poised to Take Leap in Developing a Driverless Car
item.description: Conditions for the technology may actually be more favorable in China than in the United States because of aggressive support from the government.
item.dc:creator: JOHN MARKOFF and PAUL MOZUR
item.media:description: A traffic jam in Shenzhen, China. Car ownership has spiked in China, and traffic problems plague its largest cities.

item.title: Third Man Is Charged in Belgium Over Foiled Plot in France
item.description: The 33-year-old Belgian was charged with participation in the activities of a terrorist group, the federal prosecutor’s office said Saturday.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN and SEWELL CHAN
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents in Molenbeek watched as the police advanced toward anti-Islam protesters on Saturday.

item.title: Lost in Nicaragua, a Chinese Tycoon’s Canal Project
item.description: Sixteen months after ground was broken, a plan by a Chinese billionaire that would link the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans and greatly alter a country is shrouded in mystery and controversy.
item.dc:creator: SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: In parts of Nicaragua, public images of President Daniel Ortega, including this one in Rivas, have been hit with black paint balls over his support for a canal project.

item.title: Overpass Project in Kolkata ‘Made Our Lives Hell’ for Years Before Collapse
item.description: Irritation with the faltering project, unfinished after seven years, has turned into a sort of focused hatred for the people who live beneath it.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: Rescue workers cleared debris Friday during efforts to free people trapped under a collapsed highway in Kolkata.

item.title: Gato Barbieri, Latin Jazz Trailblazer, Is Dead at 83
item.description: Leandro Barbieri, who earned the nickname Gato, recorded dozens of albums and received a Latin Grammy lifetime award in 2015.
item.dc:creator: PETER KEEPNEWS and CHRISTOPHER MELE
item.media:description: Leandro Barbieri, known as Gato, playing the tenor saxophone at the Beacon Theater in Manhattan in 2001.

item.title: Insider’s Account of How Graft Fed Brazil’s Political Crisis
item.description: A leftist party led by Dilma Rousseff that rose to power vowing to stamp out the corruption of a privileged political elite ended up embracing its predecessors’ practices.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.media:description: Delcídio do Amaral, a Brazilian senator, was arrested in November, accused of plotting to smuggle a convicted former executive of Petrobras, Brazil’s state-controlled oil company, out of the country.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Jacob Zuma Must Go
item.description: A court ruling that South Africa's president has abused his office should herald a new era of democratic accountability.
item.dc:creator: MARK GEVISSER

item.title: Israel Expands Palestinian Fishing Zone Off Gaza’s Coast
item.description: A change to nine nautical miles of the Mediterranean, from six, will allow access to areas that had been off limits for a decade.
item.dc:creator: MAJD AL WAHEIDI and ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Palestinian fishermen taking fish out of a net in Gaza on Sunday.

item.title: Memo From China: China’s Carbon Emissions May Have Peaked, but It’s Hazy
item.description: There could be important consequences if such emissions are falling more than a decade earlier than expected, but finding the answer is difficult.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Grave markers in a cemetery with smoke billowing behind them from a coal-fired power plant in Shanxi, China. Some scientists believe China’s emissions may be falling modestly, as its economy grows more slowly.

item.title: Azerbaijan Claims to Halt Fighting in Nagorno-Karabakh, but Warns Armenia
item.description: Azerbaijan laid the seeds for continued fighting over the long-disputed enclave by saying that it would keep the territory seized by its forces.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: Armenian forces fired artillery toward troops from Azerbaijan on Sunday in the town of Martakert in Nagorno-Karabakh.

item.title: Malaysian Sailors Abducted Near Philippines in Latest Act of Piracy
item.description: Four crewmen on a cargo ship were kidnapped by armed men, according to police officials, less than a week after 10 Indonesian crewmen were taken.
item.dc:creator: FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: Mikhail Lesin’s Strange Death in U.S. Follows a Fall From Russia’s Elite
item.description: Mikhail Y. Lesin, once a player in the Kremlin’s media apparatus, was found dead from “blunt force injuries” in Washington, fueling speculation of murder.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin with Mikhail Y. Lesin in 2002, when Mr. Lesin was minister of the press and instrumental in Mr. Putin’s efforts to wrest control over national television networks from the tycoons who controlled them.

item.title: ‘They Cannot Remove Me by Force’: A Strongman on Afghan Infighting
item.description: In a rare interview, Atta Muhammad Noor, the most powerful Tajik politician in northern Afghanistan, discussed his take on factional tensions.
item.dc:creator: JAWAD SUKHANYAR and ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Christoph Bangert for The New York Times
item.media:description: Atta Muhammad Noor in 2010. Though he has been dismissed, he continues to act as governor.

item.title: E.U. Suspects Russian Agenda in Migrants’ Shifting Arctic Route
item.description: The flow of refugees and migrants on the Arctic route through Russia is tiny, compared with other routes. But it has added anxiety, not to mention intrigue, to a crisis that is tearing the European Union apart.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants from African counties in a hostel in Kandalaksha, waiting to cross into Finland. The flow of refugees and migrants on the Arctic route has added a hefty dose of geopolitical anxiety.

item.title: Uncertain Economics Influence ‘Brexit’ Talk
item.description: Proponents of Britain’s exit from the European Union are trying to convince the country that any freedom it gains would not be offset by the risks to prosperity.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Mayor Boris Johnson of London says the European Union “subverts our democracy.”

item.title: News Analysis: How a Great City Could Survive Even Rob Ford
item.description: The flamboyant mayor may have embarrassed some with his antics, but he was proof of how a city can thrive.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: Rob Ford kicked off his re-election campaign at a rally in April 2014.

item.title: Guatemalan Women’s Claims Put Focus on Canadian Firms’ Conduct Abroad
item.description: Overseas subsidiaries have long acted as a shield for extractive companies, but cases describing negligence and rape could lead to new scrutiny.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rosa Elbira Coc Ich in Lote Ocho, Guatemala, where she used to live and where, she said, she was among several women gang-raped in 2007.

item.title: Fighting Between Azerbaijan and Armenia Flares Up in Nagorno-Karabakh
item.description: The heaviest fighting in years broke out in the Armenian separatist enclave, involving tanks, artillery and aircraft.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
